childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1976-1988

The smell of Silly Putty warming in your palm. The satisfying thwack of a Stretch Armstrong arm snapping back. The weight of a View-Master pressed against your face, clicking through Grand Canyon slides your family would never actually visit. Your childhood had a texture that kids raised on touchscreens will never understand—everything was physical, tactile, occasionally slightly toxic.

America threw itself a 200th birthday party the year you were born. Bicentennial red, white, and blue was everywhere—on fire hydrants, commemorative quarters, the Bicentennial Minutes that interrupted your parents' evening news. You don't remember it, but you grew up surrounded by its souvenirs.

At one, Star Wars exploded, and suddenly every toy you'd own for the next decade had a lightsaber or a spaceship. By five, you were watching MTV launch from your living room—music becoming something you watched, not just heard. You knew every frame of 'Video Killed the Radio Star.' At six, E.T. made you cry and beg your parents for Reese's Pieces. At seven, Michael Jackson's Thriller turned the King of Pop into something more than human, and you learned every move of the zombie dance.

Your school supplies were a statement of identity. Trapper Keepers with that satisfying velcro rip. Number 2 pencils with bite marks from standardized test anxiety. The smell of mimeograph paper, still damp and purple, handed out first thing in the morning. Scratch-and-sniff stickers traded like currency—the pizza one was worth three regular fruits.

Saturday mornings were sacred. You woke up before your parents, poured yourself a bowl of Cookie Crisp or Count Chocula, and planted yourself in front of the TV for four straight hours. Smurfs, Scooby-Doo, Schoolhouse Rock between programs teaching you about bills and conjunctions. If you missed an episode, you waited for summer reruns or accepted you'd never see it. There was no rewind button on broadcast.

At seven, you watched The Day After and understood, vaguely, that the world could end. Your parents tried to explain nuclear war during commercials. At ten, the Challenger exploded seventy-three seconds after launch, probably on a TV wheeled into your classroom. Christa McAuliffe was supposed to teach from space. Instead, you learned that optimism has limits, that adults don't always know what they're doing, that watching something live means you can't unsee it.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen X

Gen X. The slacker generation. The latchkey kids. The demographic asterisk between the massive Boomer cohort and the even larger Millennials—perpetually overlooked, perpetually underestimated, and honestly? Fine with it.

There are roughly 65 million of you in the US, making you the smallest living generation. Sandwiched between 76 million Boomers and 72 million Millennials. You've spent your entire adult life being ignored by marketers obsessed with Boomers and then Millennials. This has advantages. Nobody blames you for killing industries. Nobody writes think pieces about your avocado consumption. You exist in the cultural blindspot, which suits you just fine.

Your defining characteristic is skepticism hardened into reflex. You watched Watergate unfold in real time—your parents glued to hearings where every authority figure turned out to be a liar. You grew up during stagflation, gas lines, the Iranian hostage crisis that made America look impotent on the world stage. Authority figures lie, institutions fail, trust is earned, not given. Trust no one wasn't paranoia. It was pattern recognition.

You're the divorce generation. The divorce rate peaked in 1980, when you were four. More of you grew up in broken homes than any generation before. You came home to empty houses, microwaved your own dinners, did homework alone until a parent got home from work. This made you self-reliant in ways that look like detachment to people who had more supervision. You didn't have helicopter parents. You barely had parents who landed.

At {{AGE_AT_911}}, you were {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. Culturally, you invented ironic distance as a survival mechanism. Earnestness was embarrassing—it meant you could be hurt. Everything was either stupid or a joke or both. You built alternative rock, slacker comedies, and the studied pose of not caring even when you desperately did. Kurt Cobain wearing a dress on MTV wasn't fashion. It was armor. The flannel was armor. The sarcasm was armor. You can still entertain yourself without a screen. That's a superpower now.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

Rocky won Best Picture the year you were born—Sylvester Stallone punching the American Dream in the face, proving an underdog could go the distance even if he didn't win. Taxi Driver gave us 'You talkin' to me?' Network gave us 'I'm mad as hell and I'm not going to take this anymore.' All the President's Men made journalism look heroic, and your parents thought it mattered. 1976 was peak cynical '70s cinema, the last gasp before blockbusters took over.

Your childhood soundtrack started with Fleetwood Mac's Rumours (1977), which your parents played until the vinyl wore thin. The Eagles' 'Hotel California' was everywhere—that guitar outro burned into your memory before you understood what the lyrics meant. Disco peaked with the Bee Gees and Saturday Night Fever when you were one, then died so fast you barely remember it. By the time you were five, MTV launched, and music became visual. You learned Duran Duran's 'Hungry Like the Wolf' as much from the video as the song.

Television raised you as much as your parents did. Happy Days, Laverne & Shirley, Charlie's Angels, The Six Million Dollar Man—these were your babysitters. Saturday Night Live was in its first dangerous seasons, Chevy Chase falling down and saying things you weren't supposed to hear. By eight, you'd graduated to The A-Team, Knight Rider, and whatever action show let you imagine a more exciting life than suburban boredom.

Star Wars owned your childhood. You were one when it premiered, four when Empire Strikes Back revealed Vader was Luke's father (the greatest spoiler of your generation), seven when Return of the Jedi wrapped the trilogy. You don't remember a world before Star Wars because there effectively wasn't one—not for kids, not for toys, not for movies. George Lucas rewired what entertainment could be.

By adolescence, you were deep in John Hughes territory. The Breakfast Club when you were nine, Ferris Bueller's Day Off when you were ten, Pretty in Pink, Sixteen Candles—these were instruction manuals for surviving high school, for understanding that adults were clueless and your angst was valid. Molly Ringwald was your generation's face. You knew every word of 'Don't You (Forget About Me)' and raised your fist at the freeze frame.

High school brought alternative rock as your personal soundtrack. R.E.M., The Smiths, The Cure—sad music for kids who couldn't explain why they were sad. Then Nirvana's 'Smells Like Teen Spirit' detonated in 1991 when you were fifteen, and suddenly the underground was mainstream. Kurt Cobain's howl was your howl. Flannel shirts became a uniform. MTV's Unplugged sessions replaced the glossy hair-metal videos. You were there for grunge's three-year reign before it died with Kurt in 1994.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

Apple Computer was founded in a Cupertino garage the same year you were born. Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak were hand-building circuit boards while you were learning to walk. The Apple I sold for $666.66—a number that seemed punk rock before punk rock existed. The personal computer revolution was beginning, and you'd grow up alongside it, neither fully native nor completely foreign.

At three, the Sony Walkman arrived, and suddenly music was portable. You could carry your own soundtrack everywhere—on the school bus, walking to a friend's house, tuning out your parents' arguments. Those orange foam headphones became an extension of your skull. You killed thousands of AA batteries rewinding your favorite songs.

Your childhood was pre-digital but not pre-electronic. You had television (three networks, PBS, and UHF static), radio, cassette tapes you recorded off the radio with your finger hovering over the pause button to cut out commercials. VCRs arrived when you were around seven, and suddenly you could time-shift, record shows, rent movies from the new Blockbuster down the street. The tracking knob became second nature.

At nine, the IBM PC launched. At twelve, the Macintosh arrived with its friendly 'hello' and its revolutionary mouse. You used Apple IIe computers in school—green text on black screens, Oregon Trail killing your oxen and your party from dysentery. You typed papers on typewriters first, then word processors, learning to save obsessively after losing a document to a power surge once.

The internet arrived when you were in college or just after. You remember dial-up's screeching handshake, the AOL 'You've got mail' that meant something before it became a punchline. You learned email, then chat rooms, then the early web—GeoCities pages with construction-cone GIFs, search engines before Google made them good. You were early adopters but not digital natives. You learned the internet as an adult skill, like driving or taxes.

This gives you a peculiar fluency. You function without constant connectivity because you remember life without it. You can read a paper map, use a card catalog, calculate a tip without your phone. You understand technology as a tool you picked up, not an environment you were born into. You're translators between the analog world and the digital one, comfortable in both, native to neither.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were four months old when Viking 1 landed on Mars and transmitted the first photographs from another planet's surface. You don't remember it—you were busy learning to hold your head up—but it was the culmination of everything the Space Age promised. Humans were reaching beyond Earth, even if only through machines. The future was arriving on schedule.

At four, Mount St. Helens exploded, and you learned mountains could kill people. At five, Reagan was shot outside the Washington Hilton, and you watched your parents watch the news with a fear you didn't understand. That same year, AIDS was first identified, though it would be years before you understood what it meant or how it would reshape everything from dating to politics to who got to be considered human.

At five, the first Space Shuttle launched. At ten, the Challenger exploded seventy-three seconds after liftoff, probably on a television wheeled into your classroom because a teacher was going to space. Christa McAuliffe was supposed to broadcast lessons from orbit. Instead, you watched the Y-shaped smoke trail and learned that progress has costs, that live television can traumatize an entire generation simultaneously, that the adults weren't as in control as they pretended.

You grew up in the Cold War's shadow. You did duck-and-cover drills nobody believed would help. You watched The Day After and WarGames and understood, viscerally, that the world could end at any moment, that there were missiles pointed at your house right now. At thirteen, the Berlin Wall fell—people with sledgehammers chipping away at concrete while guards who would have shot them a week earlier just watched. The existential threat you'd been raised to fear evaporated overnight. You weren't sure what to replace it with.

At fifteen, the Gulf War became the first televised war—CNN's coming-out party, green night-vision footage that looked like a video game. At eighteen, the Soviet Union dissolved. The empire that had defined your childhood fears simply stopped existing. At nineteen, the World Trade Center was bombed the first time—a preview nobody recognized as a preview.

At twenty-three, Oklahoma City. At twenty-three, Columbine—though you were old enough that it felt like someone else's nightmare, high school already behind you. At twenty-five, Y2K fizzled into nothing. At twenty-five, Bush v. Gore taught you that elections could be stolen in daylight if enough powerful people agreed to look away.

At {{AGE_AT_911}}, you were {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. You were old enough to be working, to have an apartment, to understand exactly what you were watching and what it meant. You probably knew someone who knew someone. You definitely knew the skyline. The before and after of that day is cleaner for you than for younger generations. You had a quarter-century of 'before.' Everything since has been 'after.'

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You entered the workforce in the late '90s, when the NASDAQ was a rocket ship and anyone who could spell 'HTML' had a job offer. The dot-com boom felt like the rules had changed—equity over salary, ping-pong tables over pensions, twenty-three-year-olds becoming millionaires while you were still figuring out how fax machines worked. If you were lucky, you got stock options that were worth something before 2000. If you weren't, those options became expensive wallpaper.

Your generation learned the fundamental lesson of modern employment before Millennials even graduated: loyalty is a sucker's bet. You watched your parents get laid off by companies they'd given decades to—pension promises evaporating, gold watches replaced by cardboard boxes. The old social contract—work hard, stay loyal, retire with a pension—was being shredded in real time. You inherited the wreckage and adapted.

You're the generation that normalized job-hopping before it had a name. Not out of flightiness—out of self-preservation. Job security became an oxymoron. You learned to climb by moving laterally, to negotiate by having options, to keep your resume warm because your employer would replace you the moment the spreadsheet suggested it. You don't trust companies because companies gave you every reason not to.

The dot-com crash hit when you were twenty-four, wiping out the easy money and the illusion that growth only went up. You survived. At {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}, the 2008 financial crisis arrived—hopefully you were established enough to weather it, but still young enough to lose years of accumulated progress. Many of you lost houses during the subprime collapse. Many of you lost jobs. All of you lost the assumption that playing by the rules meant security.

COVID arrived when you were forty-four, maybe managing people, maybe finally in a position of authority. Suddenly you were navigating remote work, Zoom fatigue, and the realization that the office had been held together by proximity rather than necessity. You adapted because adapting is what you do. From typewriters to word processors to smartphones, from fax machines to email to Slack pinging at midnight—you've learned every system because the alternative was obsolescence. You didn't complain about it—you just did the work. That's your legacy: competence without fanfare.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Did you ever call someone's house and have to make small talk with their mom before you could ask if they were home? Did you ever wait by the phone that couldn't follow you, willing it to ring? Did you ever write a note on lined paper, fold it into an intricate triangle, and pass it across the classroom knowing interception meant social death?

You're the last generation that dated without algorithms. You met people at parties, through friends, in line at coffee shops, at record stores flipping through the same section. You exchanged phone numbers on napkins. You called and got answering machines—those actual machines with tiny cassettes—and had to decide whether to leave a message or hang up and try again, knowing the click would be recorded either way.

Your relationships evolved alongside communication technology. Landlines to cordless phones to car phones to cell phones to smartphones. Letters to faxes to emails to texts to DMs. Long-distance calls cost money—you remember the anxiety of watching the minutes tick by, knowing your parents would see the bill. You remember calling cards, 1-800-COLLECT, the innovations that made staying connected slightly less expensive.

Your generation married later than your parents but earlier than Millennials. The median marriage age for your cohort was around twenty-five—still young by today's standards. Many of you divorced, because your generation normalized divorce in ways previous generations hadn't. You saw your parents' marriages fail and learned that staying together 'for the kids' often meant staying together to traumatize the kids. Better to split than to model misery.

Friendships for Gen X tend to be smaller circles, deeper bonds, less performative than the social-media-driven connections that followed. You have friends you've known for thirty years. You don't need to post about the friendship to make it real. You're comfortable with silence in ways younger generations aren't—a friend you haven't talked to in six months is still a friend. You pick up where you left off without needing to apologize for the gap. Maintenance isn't measured in likes.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Three major economic crashes hit during your prime earning years. The dot-com crash when you were twenty-four, watching paper millionaires become regular broke people overnight. The 2008 financial collapse when you were thirty-two, learning that your house could be worth less than you paid for it, that banks could fail, that 'too big to fail' meant too big for consequences. COVID when you were forty-four, watching the market crater and recover while small businesses died and billionaires got richer.

Your financial advantages over Millennials are real but often overstated. Yes, college was cheaper when you went—a year at a state school might have been $2,000, not $20,000. Yes, houses were more affordable when you first bought—a starter home didn't require a six-figure down payment. But you also got hit by 2008 in your early thirties, when you should have been accumulating wealth. Many of you lost houses. Many of you lost jobs. The market dropped 40% in 2008, and your 401(k) dropped with it.

You're the 401(k) generation—the first to fund your own retirements instead of relying on company pensions. You watched the shift happen in real time. Defined benefits became defined contributions. Companies transferred risk from themselves to workers, called it 'empowerment,' and pocketed the savings. You had to become amateur financial planners—learning about expense ratios and asset allocation—because nobody was going to manage your retirement for you. Mortgage rates hit 18% in the early '80s when your parents were buying—you inherited their financial anxiety.

A house in 1990, when you were fourteen, cost about 2.5 times the median income. Today it's over six times. You got in early enough to benefit, but not early enough to coast.

Your relationship with money is pragmatic, shaped by watching systems fail. You save because you've seen what happens when you don't. You invest because Social Security feels like a gamble, not a guarantee. You diversify because you've watched single bets—dot-com stocks, real estate, employer stock—destroy people who trusted too much. You're not optimistic about money. You're prepared.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your biggest blind spot is mistaking cynicism for wisdom. You grew up distrustful—Watergate, stagflation, nuclear anxiety, parental divorce—and that distrust has served you well. You don't fall for scams as easily. You read the fine print. You assume the worst and are pleasantly surprised by neutral. But somewhere along the line, healthy skepticism calcified into reflexive dismissal. You reject earnestness because earnestness burned you once. But earnestness isn't always naivete, and dismissing it preemptively means missing things that matter.

You're so used to being overlooked that you've made invisibility a virtue. You pride yourself on not needing attention, on doing the work without credit, on being the competent adult in the room. But sometimes that means you don't advocate for yourself when you should. You let Boomers dominate leadership positions and Millennials dominate cultural conversations while you do the actual work of keeping systems running. Being underestimated is only an advantage if you eventually use it.

Your ironic distance reads as apathy to people who don't know the code. You care—about climate change, about inequality, about the systems failing your kids—but you're uncomfortable expressing that care without a protective layer of sarcasm. This makes it hard for younger people to take you seriously as allies. They can't tell if you're with them or mocking them from the sidelines. The armor you built in the '80s still fits, but it's become its own kind of prison.

You adapted to so many broken systems that you've forgotten they could be different. You're experts at survival within constraints—making bad jobs tolerable, making insufficient salaries stretch, making peace with injustice because fighting it seemed pointless. But survival isn't the same as thriving, and accepting constraints isn't the same as changing them. You learned to work around problems instead of demanding they be fixed. Sometimes that's wisdom. Sometimes it's capitulation.

Your self-reliance can become isolation, and you've normalized that too. You figured things out alone as latchkey kids, and you still default to handling everything yourself. Asking for help feels like weakness, like admitting the independence you built your identity around was always partly a coping mechanism. But refusing help isn't strength. It's just stubbornness with better branding, and it leaves you carrying weight you don't have to carry alone.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1996-2006): You graduated into the best economy in decades. The dot-com boom made everyone feel rich, even the people who weren't. Stock options were handed out like candy. Companies with no revenue had billion-dollar valuations. You probably had multiple jobs before thirty—not because you couldn't commit, but because the market rewarded movement and punished loyalty. This was the decade of possibility, of Pets.com and Webvan and the sincere belief that the old rules were obsolete. Then the bubble popped in 2000, and you learned the old rules were just waiting.

Your 30s (2006-2016): The 2008 financial crisis hit you in your early thirties—established enough to have something to lose, young enough that losing it meant starting over. Maybe you lost a house to the subprime collapse. Maybe you lost a job when your company 'restructured.' Maybe you just watched your 401(k) crater and learned that diversification doesn't help when everything falls at once. This was supposed to be your building decade, when career advancement and compound interest worked together to create security. Instead, it was survival. You learned that playing by the rules doesn't protect you from systemic failure.

Your 40s (2016-2026): You're here now, probably at peak earning potential, definitely at peak responsibility. Your kids, if you have them, might be teenagers discovering their own problems. Your parents are aging, starting to need more than phone calls. You're sandwiched—managing down (employees, children) and managing up (aging parents, senior leadership who won't retire). COVID hit at forty-four and proved that working from home was always possible; they just didn't want you to know. This is the decade where you either consolidate what you've built or realize you need to change course entirely. Both options are valid. Neither is easy.

Your 50s (2026-2036): The decade of reckoning approaches. Are you on track for retirement? (The honest answer is probably 'close but not quite.') How's your health? (This becomes the dominant question, slowly and then suddenly.) Do you still like your work, or just need it? Your generation will age into a healthcare system buckling under Boomer demand, which means your care will be rationed one way or another. You'll watch your parents decline. You'll become the oldest generation in your family, which is a strange and quiet transition nobody prepares you for.

Your 60s and beyond (2036+): Retirement, for most Gen Xers, won't look like your parents' version—the pension, the gold watch, the leisurely decades on Social Security that actually covered expenses. You'll probably work longer than you planned, either by choice or necessity. The goalpost will move. But here's what you have: adaptability. You've been adapting your whole life—to technology shifts, to economic crashes, to rules that changed while you were following them. One more adjustment is just Tuesday. And at least you won't be bored.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in the US the same year as you—part of the 65 million Americans classified as Gen X. That makes your generation the smallest living cohort, squeezed between 76 million Boomers who won't leave the stage and 72 million Millennials who keep being told the stage is theirs.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): They got the postwar boom, you got the post-Vietnam malaise. They bought houses for two years' salary, you bought houses for four (and counted yourself lucky). They had pensions, you had 401(k)s and the vague suggestion to 'diversify.' They spent their careers at one or two companies that rewarded loyalty; you learned loyalty was a trap by watching them get laid off anyway. They controlled 21% of national wealth at your age; you control about 9%. The math isn't close, and they don't want to hear about it.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): You're more financially stable but also more cynical. You had advantages they didn't—cheaper tuition, earlier entry into housing markets, less crushing student debt. But you also had less support, less parental involvement, less safety net. You raised yourselves while both parents worked. They were raised by helicopter parents who scheduled their playdates and intervened in their conflicts. Neither approach was perfect. Yours just hurt differently.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): You're practically prehistoric to them. You grew up without the internet; they've never known a world without it. You remember privacy, remember boredom, remember being unreachable. They've been documented since birth, tracked since adolescence, marketed to since they could swipe. You're confused by their simultaneous optimism and nihilism, their ability to meme through disaster. They seem both more fragile and more resilient than you understand. Maybe they're just adapting, the way you did. Maybe adaptation looks different now.

Your life expectancy is around 76-78 years—similar to Boomers, though your generation shows elevated rates of 'deaths of despair' (suicide, overdose, alcohol-related). You're healthier than previous generations in some ways, sicker in others. You'll need healthcare longer than your parents did and trust the system to provide it less.

You're the forgotten middle child of American generations. Not idealistic like Boomers claimed to be. Not optimistic like Millennials were before 2008 broke them. Not nihilistic like Gen Z performs online. Just pragmatic, skeptical, self-reliant to a fault, and quietly doing the work while everyone argues about who ruined what. Someone has to keep the systems running while the other generations fight. Might as well be you.

year_events: Apple Computer founded in a garage
